<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 193, 200]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 222, 170, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 422, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[617, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 903, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 177, 292]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|> 9702/33 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 359, 316]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|> February/March 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 326, 904, 340]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 699, 400]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 892, 604]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question.- You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 212, 647]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 681]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[680, 730, 904, 859]]<|/det|>
For Examiner's Use

Total
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 867, 726, 883]]<|/det|> This document has 12 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[57, 28, 413, 67]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 736, 89]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 103, 94, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 103, 594, 120]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate an electrical circuit.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 146, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 134, 500, 168]]<|/det|>
Connect the circuit shown in Fig. 1.1. E, F, G and H are crocodile clips.  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 177, 794, 416]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 435, 532, 453]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 1.1 </center>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 466, 917, 501]]<|/det|>
<pre>Using the long connecting lead, clip crocodile clips F and G on the resistance wire so that they are approximately \(0.45 \text{m}\) apart.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 514, 620, 547]]<|/det|>
<pre>The length of resistance wire between F and G is x. Measure and record x.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 605, 917, 622]]<|/det|>
<form>x = ................................................................................... m  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 636, 432, 670]]<|/det|>
<pre>The current in the circuit is \(I\). Close S and record \(I\).  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 728, 918, 745]]<|/det|>
<form>I = ................................................................................. A  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 761, 265, 777]]<|/det|>
<pre>Open S.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 775, 918, 793]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 402, 90]]<|/det|>
Change \(x\) and record \(x\) and \(I\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 88, 574, 106]]<|/det|>
Repeat until you have six sets of values of \(x\) and \(I\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 114, 677, 138]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\frac{1}{I}\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 522, 920, 540]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 552, 144, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 552, 180, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 548, 640, 575]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{I}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(x\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 553, 920, 571]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 584, 180, 603]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 584, 457, 602]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 584, 920, 603]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 616, 181, 634]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 616, 607, 634]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[497, 831, 917, 848]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ............................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 861, 917, 879]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ........................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 879, 920, 897]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 73, 737, 90]]<|/det|>
<pre>You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 103, 96, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 740, 121]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the thermal properties of plastic pipe.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 146, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 134, 598, 152]]<|/det|>
• You are provided with two lengths of plastic pipe.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 165, 747, 183]]<|/det|>
• Select one of them and, using the waterproof pen, label one end A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 197, 752, 214]]<|/det|>
• Make a mark approximately 12 cm from end A, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 225, 782, 325]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 2.1</center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 370, 710, 387]]<|/det|>
• The distance from end A to the mark is \(L\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 387, 384, 402]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(L\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 402, 917, 420]]<|/det|>
\[L = \text{......}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 433, 683, 466]]<|/det|>
• Use the thermometer to measure the room temperature \(T_0\). Record \(T_0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 462, 918, 479]]<|/det|>
<form>\[T_0 = \text{......}^{\circ}\text{C}\] </form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 479, 918, 497]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 510, 148, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 510, 180, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 510, 583, 528]]<|/det|>
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 527, 728, 543]]<|/det|>
The point Z is the lower edge of the end of the wooden strip.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 553, 880, 915]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 928, 532, 945]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 947, 550, 959]]<|/det|>
9702/33/F/M/25

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 73, 729, 90]]<|/det|>
<pre>· Ensure that end A is at the bottom of the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 104, 838, 115]]<|/det|>
<pre>The distance between the centre of the bolt and the centre of the nail is s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 119, 918, 150]]<|/det|>
The distance between the centre of the nail and the end of the wooden strip is \(d\), as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 165, 473, 180]]<|/det|>
<pre>· Measure and record \(s\) and \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 212, 915, 225]]<|/det|>
<form>s = ........................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 256, 915, 270]]<|/det|>
<form>d = ....................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 273, 920, 288]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 305, 181, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 305, 732, 320]]<|/det|>
· The distance from the bench to Z is \(H_{1}\) , as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 322, 433, 336]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(H_{1}\) .

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[542, 350, 915, 365]]<|/det|>
\[H_{1} = \text{....................................................................}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 381, 918, 412]]<|/det|>
<pre>· Slowly and carefully pour very hot water into the measuring cylinder until the water level reaches the mark on the pipe.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 413, 918, 444]]<|/det|>
The distance between the bench and Z will change. When Z reaches its lowest position the new distance from the bench to Z is \(H_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 445, 433, 459]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(H_{2}\) .

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[542, 475, 915, 490]]<|/det|>
\[H_{2} = \text{....................................................................}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 507, 725, 522]]<|/det|>
<pre>· The temperature of the water in the measuring cylinder is \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 523, 425, 537]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 567, 920, 582]]<|/det|>
<form>T = .................................................................... °C

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 585, 920, 600]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 615, 181, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 615, 390, 630]]<|/det|>
· Calculate \(H_{1} - H_{2}\) .

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[507, 630, 915, 647]]<|/det|>
\[H_{1} - H_{2} = \text{....................................................................}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 660, 737, 675]]<|/det|>
· Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(H_{1} - H_{2}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 676, 397, 690]]<|/det|>
Show your working.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 751, 920, 768]]<|/det|>
\[\text{percentage uncertainty} = \text{....................................................................} \%\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 770, 920, 785]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 816, 180, 833]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 806, 542, 834]]<|/det|>
· Calculate \(\Delta L\) where \(\Delta L = \frac{s(H_1 - H_2)}{d}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[542, 908, 915, 923]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\Delta L =\) .................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 562, 90]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(\Delta L\) , \(L\) , \(T\) and \(T_0\) are related by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 103, 564, 120]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta L = kL(T - T_0)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 338, 151]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 166, 512, 182]]<|/det|>
Using your data, calculate two values for \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 351, 912, 368]]<|/det|>
<form>first value of \(k =\) ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 382, 912, 399]]<|/det|>
<form>second value of \(k =\) ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 399, 920, 416]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 429, 144, 447]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 429, 750, 446]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the percentage uncertainty in the values of \(k\) is \(30\%\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 444, 826, 461]]<|/det|>
Using this uncertainty, explain whether your results support the relationship in (d).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 476, 915, 508]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 692, 920, 710]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 183, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 917, 120]]<|/det|>
Describe **four** sources of uncertainty or limitations of the procedure for this experiment. For any uncertainties in measurement that you describe, you should state the quantity being measured and the reason for the uncertainty.
